title: SB 231
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Projects eligible for funding under Section 75212 of the Public Resources Code include intermodal affordable housing, transit capital projects, active transportation projects, noninfrastructure-related active transportation projects, and transit-oriented development projects. Projects eligible for funding under Section 75212 of the Public Resources Code include capital projects for local complete streets programs, programs to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and vehicle miles traveled, acquisition of easements to protect agricultural lands, and planning to support sustainable communities strategies. The Low Carbon Transit Operations Program is created to assist transit agencies in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and improving mobility, with a focus on disadvantaged communities. Funding for the program is continuously appropriated from the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund. The Controller allocates funding based on requirements and guidelines developed by the Department of Transportation. The Low Carbon Transit Operations Program provides funding for transit agencies to enhance transit services, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and increase mode share through new or expanded services and facilities. The Department of Transportation, in coordination with the State Air Resources Board, will develop guidelines for transit agencies to demonstrate how at least 50% of received funds will benefit disadvantaged communities as per Section 39711 of the Health and Safety Code. Compliance with criteria in subdivisions (d) and (e) must be documented for ongoing reporting. The Department of Transportation, in coordination with the State Air Resources Board, will develop guidelines for transit agencies to demonstrate how funds will benefit disadvantaged communities. Transit agencies must submit proposed expense types and documentation for fund disbursement eligibility. The Department of Transportation will notify the Controller of approved expenditures for each transit agency and the allocated amount. Recipient transit agencies must provide annual reports in the prescribed format to ensure compliance with guidelines for maximizing benefits to disadvantaged communities.
